channel.title: Comments on: Cheatsheet: Relational Database Management Systems Comparison
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Scott Levy
item.dc:creator: Scott Levy
item.description: Great post. Here’s a tutorial that shows how you can easily build an online database-driven web application with a parent-child table relationship, without codinghttp://blog.caspio.com/web-database/creating-one-to-many-relational-datapages/
item.content:encoded: Great post. Here’s a tutorial that shows how you can easily build an online database-driven web application with a parent-child table relationship, without codinghttp://blog.caspio.com/web-database/creating-one-to-many-relational-datapages/

item.title: By: SQLDenis

item.description: The installer for PostgreSQL is a pleasure to work with....the Oracle one on the other hand is pure crap
item.content:encoded: The installer for PostgreSQL is a pleasure to work with….the Oracle one on the other hand is pure crap

item.title: By: Justin Dearing
item.dc:creator: Justin Dearing
item.description: PGadmin is not as pretty or functional as SSMS, but its pretty polished. Also, the windows MSIs of postgres have been pretty polished for the past couple of years.
item.content:encoded: PGadmin is not as pretty or functional as SSMS, but its pretty polished. Also, the windows MSIs of postgres have been pretty polished for the past couple of years.

item.title: By: Jes Schultz Borland (grrlgeek)
item.dc:creator: Jes Schultz Borland (grrlgeek)
item.content:encoded:
Justin – thanks for the great info!

I also was given a link to pgAdmin, an “administration and development tool for PostgreSQL” – http://www.pgadmin.org/.

item.title: By: Justin Dearing
item.dc:creator: Justin Dearing
item.content:encoded:
Jes,

Your assessment that postgres has no vendor support, but does have third party support is technically accurate. However, CommandPrompt, EnterpriseDB, and and other third party support providers also contribute to the core product. Since there is no postgres “vendor” that has clear ownership of the copyright, but companies that employ code contributors full time, you end up with something close to vendor support.

Alos, you can buy a non-free closed source forke from these vendors that they have complete control over, and are more likely to customize than Microsoft or Oracle.

CommandPrompt community contributors: http://www.commandprompt.com/community/
EnterpriseDB community contributors: http://www.enterprisedb.com/resources-community/enterprisedb-community-contributions

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.description: I suppose it's not just the database engine that's important, but also the version and edition of the database engines. For example, SQL Server 2005 Express vs. SQL Server 2008 R2 Enterprise.
item.content:encoded: I suppose it’s not just the database engine that’s important, but also the version and edition of the database engines. For example, SQL Server 2005 Express vs. SQL Server 2008 R2 Enterprise.
